header.title: Leabhar Toghairm: The Book of Summoning

central_thesis: This book presents a modern Druidic magical system, informed by ancient Indo-European rites and grimoire traditions, for establishing active, relational partnerships with spiritual beings (Gods, Dead, and Noble Ones) through offerings, invocations, and trancework, with a focus on practical magical results rather than coercive command.

structure_content.summary: Discusses the historical context of Neo-Paganism, contrasting 'occult energies' magic with traditional spirit-contact magic. The author’s Druidry (ADF) blends Indo-European and other polytheistic influences. It reinterprets grimoire traditions into a polytheistic, animistic, and relational framework, rejecting Judeo-Christian dualism and coercive spirit control.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 1: The Order of the Worlds & the Spirits
structure_content.summary: Outlines the core cosmology: the Nine-Fold Cosmos (Three Worlds: Annwn, Abred, Gwynvyd; Three Realms: Sea, Land, Sky; Threefold Center: Fire, Well, Tree) and the Three Kindreds of Spirits (na Marbh/Dead, na Sprideanna/Spirits/Noble Ones, na Dheithe/Deities/Shining Ones). Introduces 'Bri' (intrinsic power) and 'Bua' (gathered power) as distinct forms of magical energy and 'An Fuinneamh Deach' (The Two Powers: Underworld/Chaos of Potential and Heavens/Pattern of World Order). Defines the Common World and Otherworld.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 2: Concerning the Daemons & the Dead
structure_content.summary: Explores the nature of the Sidhe as 'De ocus an-De' (Gods and Not-Gods), drawing parallels with the Hellenic concept of 'daemons' as divine agents. Spirits are classified within the Three Realms (Underworld, Midrealm, Heavens) and categorized using 'Celtic Elementals' (Duile Sigils: Stone, Soil, Vegetation, Sea, Wind, Cloud, Moon, Sun, Stars) to identify specific types of wights for magical work. The social structure of Sidhe Courts (King, Queen, Wise Ones, Warriors, Yeomen) and the duality of Seelie/Unseelie Courts are described. Practical sigils for calling spirits are introduced.

Details the magician's personal development, emphasizing Self-Knowledge, Knowledge of Lore (Celtic and Indo-European), and the practice of Meditation & Austerities to build 'bua'. Specific trance techniques like 'Fire & Water Entrancement', 'Bone, Breath & Blood', and 'The Two Powers' are given. The 'Dual Sight' or 'Vision Eye' and the concept of the 'Threshold Realm' are central for direct spirit perception. Attunement to the Land and regular Preliminary Rituals (Hearth Cult, Year Cult, Personal Cult) are crucial foundations.

Presents foundational rituals for establishing and maintaining relationships with spirits. This includes 'An Incense of Offering & Blessing', 'A Simple Charm of Hallowing', and 'Simple Purification by Fire & Water'. The overarching 'Outline of Druidic Sacrificial Ritual' serves as a template for all major workings, detailing steps from preparation and opening the grove to offering to spirits, receiving blessings, and closing. A 'Full Simple Rite of Sacrifice' and 'A Shorter Grove Opening' are provided as practical examples.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 5: The First Cycle: Making the Tools
structure_content.summary: Focuses on the creation and hallowing of physical magical tools. Instructions are given for establishing a 'Home Shrine' with the three Hallows (Fire, Well, Tree). Detailed methods for crafting and consecrating the 'Cauldron' (Coire Beannachta) and 'Wand' (Slat Draoi) as expressions of Underworld and Heaven Powers are provided. The making of a 'Warding Charm' (The Shielding) with specific ingredients (Rowan, iron nail, hematite/bloodstone) and conjuring words (Faire, Cosaint, Conoi) is also described.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 6: The Second Cycle: Meeting the Kindreds
structure_content.summary: Outlines a series of progressive rites designed for direct, personal meetings with the Three Kindreds. These include preliminary preparations ('Welcoming Charm', 'Ritual Bath', 'Armoring', 'Concerning Warding') and specific 'Audience Rites' for the Earth Mother & Gatekeeper, the Dead (involving the creation of a 'Cauldron of the Dead' fetish for ancestral contact), and the Nobles (including the construction of a 'Cairn of the Spirits' for landwight alliances). The emphasis is on inviting and dialoguing with spirits through offerings and trance vision.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part 7: The Third Cycle: Making Alliances
structure_content.summary: Details the process of forming specific, individual alliances with spirits. This involves creating 'Summoning Earth' (ashes, blood, graveyard earth) and 'Signs of Power' (a disk/stone with the 'Cloak & Spear' sigil and 'Signs of Calling'). Rites for 'Calling the Ancestral Teacher' and 'Calling the Familiar' are provided, emphasizing mutual pacts rather than master-slave relationships. The 'Sorcerer's Sacrifice' is presented as a ritual for personal empowerment and securing alliances.

Focuses on the practical application of summoning for specific magical tasks. The 'Summoning Cauldron' is introduced as a 'magic mirror' used within a 'Triangle of Manifestation' to evoke spirits, with intent sigils directing the summoning. The 'Convoking the Host of the Sidhe' ritual details a three-day preparation and a full rite for summoning the local spirit host en masse, engaging with individual spirits, and recording their names, natures, and proper offerings for future work. The importance of maintaining authority and ethical conduct is stressed.

Explores advanced spirit work, including tasking a familiar to find agents for specific magical needs, using 'The Pendulum Oracle Charm' for direct spirit communication and divination (yes/no questions, or indicating letters/runes on a board). Three formulae for specific practical goals are detailed ('Spirit Warders', 'Glamour for Love', 'Questioning the Dead'), each with tailored sigils, offerings, and elemental correspondences. The 'Bounty Cauldron' and 'Wand & Cauldron Will-Working' are presented for prosperity magic and general spell execution, integrating the central tools with the cosmological model. The book also lists 'Nine Druidic Telesmata', which appear to be key ritual components or concepts.

key_concepts.definition: The innate meaning, ability, power, and/or talent intrinsic to a person, place, or thing, constant in amount but can be utilized or allowed to atrophy. Associated with Underworld Power.
The power, meaning, ability, or form placed upon or within any person, place, or thing by the will and work of a being, accumulated through deeds and strength. Associated with Sky Power.

A Celtic cosmological map structured around three triplicities: Three Worlds (Annwn/underworld, Abred/midworld, Gwynvyd/heavens), Three Realms (An Muir/Sea, An Talamh/Land, An Speir/Sky), and a Threefold Center (An Teinne/Fire, An Tobar/Well, An Crann/Tree).

The primary categories of spirit hosts: na Marbh (The Dead/Mighty Ones/blessed ancestors), na Sprideanna (The Spirits/Noble Ones/other kins, nature spirits), and na Dheithe (The Deities/Shining Ones/eldest, wisest, mightiest Gods and Goddesses).

The primal divine powers underlying existence: Underworld (Chaos of Potential, associated with Danu/Anu) and Heavens (Pattern of the World Order, associated with Bel/Bile). Druidic magicians learn to move these powers within the body for magical purposes.
The spirit counterpart of the material world, present everywhere and no place in particular, reflecting and growing from the material world. Approached as local variations in a single continuum.

Three central holy tools that form the sacred Center of the Sacrifice Ground: the Sacred Fire (An Altóir na Tine), the Holy Well (An Tobar-Choire, represented by a cauldron), and the World Tree/Pillar (An Crann Domhan/An Bile, a pole or stone).

A trance technique where the 'Vision-body' is slightly 'loosened' to perceive the 'Threshold reality' of the ritual space alongside physical vision. It allows direct perception and communication with spirits.
A half-constructed, half-discovered imaginal world 'Between' the common world and the Other Places, where spirits can be encountered. It acts as a medium for reflection of both worlds.

Nine components of the natural world and human self used for classifying spirits: Stone (cloch=bone), Soil (talam=flesh), Vegetation (fasra=hair), Sea (muir=blood), Wind (gaeth=breath), Cloud (nel=brains/thoughts), Moon (eisce=mind), Sun (grian=face), Stars (rind=spirit).

The Gaelic category for the spirit hosts, encompassing both the Gods and the various lesser beings ('Not-Gods') including nature spirits and the mortal dead. Often used interchangeably with 'daemons'.
A central magical tool representing the Heaven Power, used as a scepter of authority, a conduit for will, an amplifier for invocation, and a beacon of light.

A central magical tool representing the Underworld Power, serving as a vessel for blessings, a source of magic, a 'magic mirror' for visions, and a physical manifestation of the primal well of wisdom.
A mixture of ashes from a sacred fire, nine drops of the sorcerer's blood/semen/menstruum, and graveyard earth, used to establish authority among spirits and for conjuring.

practical_system.description: The system presented is a progressive, operative magical path rooted in modern Druidry, focusing on building personal power ('bua') and forming alliances with the Three Kindreds of Spirits (Gods, Dead, Noble Ones). It emphasizes a relational, reciprocal approach ('do ut des') rather than command, operating within a Celtic Nine-Fold Cosmos anchored by the Hallows (Fire, Well, Tree). The magician develops the 'Dual Sight' for inner vision and uses divination for spirit communication. Rituals progressively deepen engagement from daily offerings to formal summoning and pact-making, culminating in the ability to 'Get Things Done' through allied spirits for practical magical goals.

relevant_quotes.text: This works intends to be an answer to those objections. In it I will present a model of spirit arte informed by the grimoiric process, but applied in a polytheistic, animistic context. The work at hand is done under the rulership of the Gaelic Gods and Goddesses, worshipped in our Druidic way with sacrifice and praise. The approach to the spirits is animistic and relational. Drawing lessons from modern polytheistic systems we base our work on offering and blessing, on do ut des (I give, so that you may give), as the Romans said it. Instead of the grimoiric oppositional relationship with the Spirits, we enter into a relational one.

The basic construction of the sacred Cosmos in the magical and religious systems of northern Europe is based around three triplicities of symbols in which dwell a triad of beings. This Nine-Fold cosmos is a different map of sacred space than many western magicians are used to using, but it salves a number of problems inherent in the strange mix of Neoplatonism and Christian mythology that inspires many modern systems.

In a proper spirit of piety, it is customary not to seek to summon the Gods to make pacts for common worldly goals. We sacrifice to them, and we seek their blessing, and we might ask specific petitions, but if we have a need we cannot expect the Shining Ones to act as our agents. So we make that basic distinction – the Gods and the Not-Gods. We can surely ask the God to send us a daemon, one that is willing to obey us and work with us for whatever intention we seek. When the sacrifice is worked well and we are filled with the Blessing of the God, we can speak with power, and the spirits will answer with respect.

This system is meant to be worked inside a ‘religious’ framework in which the Gods and Spirits are given regular worship and offering, asking no more than a general blessing in return. This builds the primary level of personal respect that makes it possible to treat with the spirits with honor.

The ritual tools are reliably connected to Gaelic lore. They also have resonances with motifs from many other cultures, and they express the very cross-cultural three-fold Cosmology discussed previously. To work with the Sacred Fire and Holy Well is to leave renaissance and early-modern magic behind, for a more archaic place.

Sacrifice is the giving of gifts to the Powers in their honor, and in return for their aid and blessing. The Wise know that our offerings strengthen the Powers as their blessings strengthen us. We offer freely of our wealth and skill in honor to the God/desses and Spirits. The sacrificial relationship between mortals and the Gods and Spirits is the core of Pagan religion. It is the web of mutual obligation that binds the worlds together.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book offers a unique and highly relevant contribution to modern Western Esotericism, particularly within Neo-Pagan Druidry. It directly addresses the perceived limitations and 'unpagan' elements of traditional grimoire magic by recontextualizing its operative principles within an animistic, polytheistic, and relational framework grounded in Celtic lore. By providing a structured system for interacting with spirits based on reciprocity and alliance rather than coercion, it bridges historical occult practice with contemporary Pagan ethics and cosmology. The integration of Celtic elemental classifications (Duile) and specific Hallows into grimoiric processes provides a distinct and comprehensive magical grammar for practitioners seeking 'authentic' yet adaptable spirit work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of experienced Neo-Pagans and Druids (especially those within ADF or similar traditions) who possess a foundational understanding of Celtic cosmology and ritual. It is also highly suitable for occult practitioners from other traditions who are interested in exploring grimoire magic from a non-dualistic, animistic perspective, or who seek to develop deep, reciprocal relationships with spirit entities. The emphasis on 'self-knowledge,' 'trancework,' and 'attunement to the land' suggests a practitioner dedicated to rigorous personal development alongside ritual practice. While basics are covered, prior exposure to pagan worship, meditation, and a willingness to commit to long-term ritual work are beneficial for successful engagement with the system.
